Problem:
Consider a heat equation \\(u_t = \\kappa \\Delta u\\) where \\(\\kappa\\) is the heat conductivity coefficient, and \\(\\Delta\\) is the Laplacian operator. Let's analyze the introduction of an external heat source \\(h(x, t)\\), which varies over time and space, via the modification of the equation to \\(u_t = \\kappa \\Delta u + h(x, t)\\).

Will the solution \\(u(x,T)\\) to the modified heat equation with a specific heat source \\(h(x, t)\\) at time T be the same as it would have been under the original heat equation at the same time and initial condition?
Explanation: The addition of the heat source \\(h(x, t)\\) alters the heat distribution within the system by adding energy at varying rates and positions, thus changing the solution \\(u(x, T)\\) compared to the scenario with no external source.
